info.description:
The CAPA API aims to be a comprehensive REST interface allowing the programmatic retrieval of **all** the content that we have available (subject to licensing agreements). It is available as a premium addon to your existing CAPA Membership. # Mailing List To keep up-to-date with the latest changes and new features added to the API, please [subscribe to our developers mailing list](http://eepurl.com/dgTbvb). # Rate Limiting API requests are rate-limited using a leaky bucket algorithm. This is to ensure that any badly written or unexpectedly popular applications don't overload the API. The current maximum bucket capacity is 45 and this is subject to change. An `X-Rate-Limit` header will be returned with every request that is subject to rate limiting. It will contain two values separated by a slash - the first value will be how "full" your bucket is and the second will be the size of the bucket. Once these two values are equal, no more requests will be accepted. The token bucket empties at a rate of 1 per second, allowing you to burst requests, so long as the total number stays below 45. For example, `X-Rate-Limit: 10 / 45` means that your token bucket is 10 requests full. If you waited a second, the value would be `9 / 45`, and 5 seconds later after that it would be `4 / 45`. If you were to keep hitting the server with requests then it would eventually reach `45 / 45` and subsequent requests would return a `429` error. Wait one second and it'd be `44 / 45`, or wait 45 seconds and you'll be back down to `1 / 45` on the next request. # Response Formats All responses are returned as a JSON object containing one or more keys:
Key Description
data If data is returned from the request, it will be contained within this key.
errors If the request has resulted in one or more errors, then the errors will be returned as an array of objects containing the closest HTTP status code that would match the error, along with a short description of the error.
meta If there's any useful data related to the request, it will appear in this key (ie. when pulling down codeshares for an airline, the meta key will contain a value listing the maximum codeshares for all airlines).
The only deviation from this format is successful responses to OAuth token requests - they don't use the data key, instead everything is inside the root object. # Versioning The CAPA API is unversioned. Unfortunately we don't have the resources to do API versioning. The documentation here will always reflect the most recent iteration of the API. Once a new resource is added, it is unlikely that its output format will change much. In any cases where there are new features added, we will endeavour to keep the output in a forwards-compatible format, adding keys but not changing existing ones. Having said that though, it is possible that occasionally there will be refactoring or removal done of existing APIs. In the instances where this happens, ample notice will be given to consumers of those resources so they can update their applications. # Data Licensing **IMPORTANT**: There are some data sets you will be unable to access via the API, due to the licensing agreements we have with the providers. At the moment these are: * **Schedules**: this cannot be accessed via API for third parties, due to our licensing agreement with OAG. * **Low Cost Carrier Penetration**: this cannot be accessed via API for third parties, due to our licensing agreement with OAG. * **Airport charges**: this cannot be accessed via API for third parties, due to our licensing agreement with ATRS. In all cases it may be possible for us to organise an agreement between you, CAPA, and various data providers in order to enable access to these APIs for your application. Contact us for more information. # IATA Codes Are Not Unique An important thing to remember when dealing with airline profiles is that **IATA codes are not unique**. They are frequently treated as unique identifiers for airlines, and in *most* cases they will be unique, but not all cases. An example is Silk Way West and Aerocaribbean - both use a code of 7L. If you're interested in why IATA codes aren't unique (it boils down to legacy reservation systems being reluctant to rewrite their software to allow for more than 2 characters), [Wikipedia has a good article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline_codes#IATA_airline_designator). # Schedule Types There are numerous types of schedule, identified by one (or more) letters. They are listed below:
Identifier Schedule type
A Additional cargo/mail service
C Charter passengers only
F Cargo/mail service with loose loaded cargo and/or preloaded devices
G Additional normal passenger service
J Normal passenger service
M Mail only
Q Passenger/cargo in cabin (combi)
S Passenger shuttle mode
U Passenger service operated by surface vehicle
V Cargo/mail service operated by surface vehicle
We include schedules of type **J, S, F, Q, G, C** in capacity counts. # Traffic Restriction Codes Some schedules operate under traffic restrictions. This affects which schedules are displayed, as well as how we count capacity. A list of traffic restriction codes are below:
Code Restriction
A no local traffic
B local traffic only
C local and domestic connecting traffic only
D qualified international online connecting or stopover traffic only
E qualified international online connecting or stopover traffic only
F local and online connecting traffic only
G qualified online connecting traffic only
H segment not to be displayed
I technical landing
K connecting traffic only
M international online stopover taffic only
N international connecting traffic only
O international online connecting traffic only
Q international online connecting or stopover traffic only
T online stopover traffic only
V connecting or stopover traffic only
W international connecting or stopover traffic only
X online connecting or stopover traffic only
Y online connecting traffic only
Z traffic restrictions do not apply equally to passenger/cargo/mail
We include unrestricted flights in our capacity counts, as well as any operating under **B, C, F** restrictions. # Profile Types Every profile within the CAPA system is assigned a "type" - this denotes what kind of a profile it is. It could be an airline, airport, country, lessor, MRO entity, supplier, government body... there's a lot to choose from. When referencing any profile, you will need to know its ID and type ID in order to pull down the correct data. The current profile type IDs are listed below. Crossed-out ones are no longer used.
ID Type
1 Airlines
2 Airports
3 Lessors
4 Countries
5 Regions
6 Metaregions
7 Industry Associations
8 Global
9 Aircraft
10 Airline Groups
11 Alliances
12 Suppliers
13 Tourism
14 Events
15 Investors
16 New Airports (aka. airports that are under construction)
17 Post Events
18 Air Traffic Management
19 Government Bodies
20 Hot Issues
21 Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul (MRO)
22 Travel Management
# Resizing Images Image URLs that are returned from the CAPA API point to the full-sized original image. Normally you do not want to display this image to customers, as most images are often huge and their file sizes are in the range of 4MB or over. The CAPA image server can automatically resize and cache images on-the-fly, if you modify the requested URL to include resize parameters. For example, if you requested an image with a URL of: `https://images.cdn.centreforaviation.com/stories/new_image_database/locations/london_bridge_Airplane_window_cityscape.jpg` ...then you'd end up with a 23.7MB file with dimensions of 7304x5088 pixels. That is completely impractical for almost all use cases. To resize it to something usable, you can specify the height required: `https://images.cdn.centreforaviation.com/stories/new_image_database/locations/london_bridge_Airplane_window_cityscape-1200x.jpg` This will output an image that is 1200 pixels wide and 151KB, which is much more usable. If you wanted to resize it by the height instead of the width: `https://images.cdn.centreforaviation.com/stories/new_image_database/locations/london_bridge_Airplane_window_cityscape-x800.jpg` Now you've got an image that has been resized to 800 pixels height and 142KB. You can also force dimensions to stretch images: `https://images.cdn.centreforaviation.com/stories/new_image_database/locations/london_bridge_Airplane_window_cityscape-1200x300.jpg` That will give you an image that has been stretched to 1200x300 pixels. Note that you can only resize downwards. If you try to resize an image up further than its original dimensions, the original image will be returned instead of a resized one. # Regions vs Metaregions There are two levels of "region" within the CAPA system. The first is regions, which are groupings of countries in the same geographic area. The second is metaregions, which are groupings of regions in the same geographic area. For example, a region may be Western Europe and contain Western European countries, but a metaregion of Europe would contain a region of Western Europe. # Troubleshooting This section lists common problems and gotchas when using the CAPA API. ## Content-Type headers All requests should have a `Content-Type: application/json` header, otherwise your payload will likely not be parsed.
info.title: CAPA API

externalDocs.description: More information on how to use OAuth

post.description:
Gets an access token for the user.

**IMPORTANT**: Note that this is a description of the POST method for /account/token which **may not be what you're looking for**. If you want to know the basics of obtaining an access token, see the [OAuth documentation](https://centreforaviation.com/assets/files/help/How%20to%20use%20OAuth.pdf).

parameters.name: Content-Type
parameters.description: You **must** send a Content-Type header. You'll receive (misleading) errors otherwise.

200.description:
A successful response will result in token details being returned.

For subsequent requests, you want to send through an authorization header with the access token in the usual OAuth format.

For example: `Authorization: Bearer 85d5ff48b88ba4cf6cfff538830f157eb373932f537de18a4b04e4a993c5803f1db2dbda29cbff536ce9499c663fc7a576091130645cd9e39ce9a3df6b1b3bfe`

schema.description: **IMPORTANT**: Note that unlike every other API response, the object returned here does **not** contain a `data` key - everything is inside the root.

access_token.description: The access token for the user.

expires_in.description: Number of seconds until the access token expires.

username.description:
User's username.

Required for a password grant.

password.description:
User's password.

Required for a password grant.

grant_type.description:
Type of grant.

**IMPORTANT**: Note that third-party clients are unable to use the `password` grant.

refresh_token.description: If you're doing a token refresh grant, then you need to send through the refresh token that you already have.

code.description: If you are logging in via an authorization code, put it here.

redirect_uri.description: If doing an authorization code grant, this parameter needs to be sent and it needs to match the redirect_uri that was in the original authorization query string.

get.summary: Get an authorization code
get.description: This will obtain an authorization code for use in an authorization code grant. Normally you don't want to access this, instead follow the information on [obtaining an access token](#text_getting_an_access_token) for the proper login flow.

parameters.name: client_id
parameters.description: The application ID.

parameters.name: response_type
parameters.description: The response type required. This will always be "code".

parameters.name: redirect_uri
parameters.description: The URL to redirect to upon a successful authorization.

parameters.name: scope
parameters.description: The scope. We only have one at the moment - "user".

302.description: A successful response will result in a 302 redirect happening - the redirect url will be the redirect_uri parameter that was sent, with `?code={code}` appended to the end of it. The code parameter is what you want to send when requesting an access token.

get.summary: Get account ID
get.description: Get the account ID associated with the current login token

data.description: The user's ID.

post.description:
Creates a new user account.

If a valid access token is sent with this request, the account created will be a subaccount of the account that the access token belongs to.

data.description: The newly created account ID.

username.description: User's username. If omitted, the username will be set to the account's email address.

password.description:
User's password.

Password must be 8 characters or longer, and contain at least one uppercase character, one lowercase character, and one number.

phone.description:
User's phone number.

This is required for new accounts, but optional for subaccounts.

company.description:
User's company.

This is required for new accounts, but optional for subaccounts.

sector.description:
User's industry sector. This is a integer that represents the sector. A list of sectors and their IDs can be accessed at [/site/sectors](#operation_get_available_industry_sectors).

This is required for new accounts, but optional for subaccounts.

country.description: User's country. This is an integer that represents the country. A list of countries and their IDs can be accessed at [/site/countries](#operation_get_a_list_of_countries).

source.description: Account creation source (used to track lead sources).

trial.description: If the account should be on a trial, this sets up a request for it.

get.summary: Get account details
get.description:
This returns the user's account details.

The account ID may be the user's own ID, or the ID of an account that the user has ownership over.

owner.description: If the account is a subaccount, this is the owner account's details.

manager.description: The details of the account manager assigned to the account.

position.description: The user's position, or job title.

postcode.description: The user's postcode or ZIP code.

created.description: UNIX timestamp of the time the account was created.

bounced.description: If true, then the account's email address is marked as having bounced.

mailok.description: It is OK to send email to this user.

position.description: The user's position or job title.

postcode.description: The user's postcode or ZIP code.

get.summary: Check if an email address is already in use
get.description: This will return true value if an email address is already in use by an account.

404.description: A 404 error will be returned if the email address is not in use.

put.description:
Reset the current user's password. This is used in cases where the user has forgotten their password and is unable to log in.

If the user is logged in and wishes to change their password, then use the resource at /account/{id}/password

400.description: An invalid reset token was sent.

token.description: Password reset token. This is sent to the user via email when they request a password reset.

post.summary: Get a reset token for a user's password
post.description: If the user has forgotten their password, posting here will generate a reset token they can use to reset it.

data.description: A response string, indicating that a reset token was sent to the email address on file for the account.

400.description: A 400 will be returned if no username was sent.

404.description:
A 404 will be returned if:

* the username does not match an account
* or if the account does not seem to have a valid email address on file

put.description: Change a user's password. :!: If you are a master account wanting to change a subaccount's password, the OAuth authorisation header needs to be sent, and the `oldPassword` value needs to be set to the master account's password.

400.description: The new password isn't long or complex enough.

401.description: The user's current password was wrong.

403.description: The user has a shared account (editing of details is disabled on shared accounts).

oldPassword.description: The user's current password. If a master account is editing the subaccount's password, this should be the password of the master account.

get.summary: Get the user's active subscriptions
get.description:
This returns an object that contains objects that represent each active subscription a user has. The key of each object will be the ID of the product.

If a subscription object contains a key called "included" that is true (along with name and shortname), and "email" that may be true or false, that means that the product with that ID is an included subscription with their account - ie. AVAN and Airline Leader will always be included subscriptions, no matter the account type. If it is an actual subscription, then the object will contain far more detailed information, which is shown below.

Note that the output for this call is pretty messy and unstable; it will eventually be changed to something a bit more ordered.

{prodID}.description: The key for each value returned is the product ID.

subid.description: The subscription ID (not the same as the product ID).

start.description: UNIX timestamp of the time the subscription started.

trial.description: Boolean indicating whether the subscription is a trial or not.

expiry.description: UNIX timestamp of the time the subscription is due to expire.

users.description: Number of user licences for the subscription.

owner.description: The ID of the subscription owner.

info.description: If this is a paid subscription, then the info key will exist with further details.

id.description: This is the subscription ID. Same as above.

cid.description: CID is "customer ID" aka the owner ID of the subscription. If the user's account is a subaccount, and the subscription is assigned then this will be the ID of the owner account.

username.description: The username of the account that owns the subscription.

company.description: The company that owns the subscription.

name.description: The name of the account that owns the subscription.

orderid.description: The order ID that the subscription is associated with.

trial.description: Whether this is a trial subscription or not.

prodid.description: The product ID of the subscription. Same as the main object key.

start.description: UNIX timestamp of the subscription start date (same as main object).

expiry.description: UNIX timestamp of the subscription expiry date (same as main object).

active.description: Boolean indicating whether this subscription is active or not (same as main object).

users.description: Number of user licences this subscription has (same as main object).

itemname.description:
This will be either a string or null, and is set when the product has been renamed in the original order that set up the subscription.

Basically, if this is not null then treat it as the product name instead of the prodname key.

email.description: Whether this subscription has a mailout component or not (ie. Fleets does not, but APAD does).

included.description: If this is an "included" subscription, this will be true. An included subscription will be something like AVAN or AL on all accounts, or APAD/ABD/etc for CAPA Membership accounts.

shortname.description: The shortname of the product. This key only exists for included subscriptions. Look inside the "info" key otherwise.

name.description: The name of the product. This key only exists for included subscriptions. Look inside the "info" key otherwise.

get.summary: Get a list of bought items
get.description: This returns all bought items that the user has associated with the account. This will be all non-subscription items, like reports.

price.description: The product's price. If this is a subscription, then the price will be the setup fee for the subscription.
Subscription price for the specified period.

mailout.description: Boolean, if true then this product has a mailout component (eg. APAD).

type.description: Product type. At the moment this contains only 0 or 1: 1 indicates the product is a report.

requires.description: If this product is an addon to another product, this is the ID of the product that is required.

updated.description: If the preferences have successfully updated, this will be true.

403.description: You'll get a 403 if the user has a shared account.

schema.description: Note that the user's mailouts will be replaced with the details of this object. This means if a product is missing from the list or has subscribe set to false, it will be deleted.

subscribe.description: Whether to receive email for this product or not.

delete.description: Making a DELETE request to this resource will unsubscribe the user from a mailout. It does not require authentication, and its intention is to be used for unsubscribe links in emails.

schema.description: A 200 response will always be received whether or not the user was already subscribed to the publication.

get.summary: Get a list of the user's subaccounts

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The user's ID.

get.summary: List all shop items
get.description: Use this resource to pull down a list of items available for purchase/subscription. The list returned will be alphabetically ordered by product name.

parameters.name: num
parameters.description: Number of results to return.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: Zero-based index of the result page number.

get.summary: Get a shop item
get.description: Returns a single shop item based on the ID provided.

parameters.name: itemid
parameters.description:
Shop item ID.

This is a bit of a weird situation. You can either use the shop item ID, or the shortname value for the shop item. Both will return the same result. Note that this only applies to this resource and not file downloads.

get.summary: Download a file from an item
get.description: If a shop item had files available for download, make a get request to this URL and it will respond with the file contents.

200.description: The content returned will be the file content. There is no JSON object returned on a successful result, only pure file data.

schema.description: Upon a successful order completion, the below data will be returned. In addition to this, the user will receive an email containing a PDF of their invoice, and (optionally) a receipt if the order has been paid by credit card. If the order contains file downloads, they will be listed within the email received as well.

paid.description: Whether the order has been paid or not. This will be true if the order was paid by credit card, otherwise it will be false and will remain unpaid until payment has been received.

400.description: Bad request results will happen if the items in the cart are of a different currency, the user does not have a required item in their cart or account, or the credit card charge failed.

coupon.description: Discount coupon code for the order.

method.description:
The payment method. These are:

| ID | Method |
| ----- | ----- |
| 1 | Credit card |
| 2 | Bank Transfer |
| 3 | Cheque |

name.description: The user's name. This can be the same as the user's name, or a different name. It is used for invoicing.

email.description: The user's email address. If this is not the same as the account's email address, then the invoice will be sent to both the account's email address and the email address listed here.

suburb.description: The user's suburb, for invoicing purposes.

country.description: The user's country ID. Get a list of countries from [/site/countries](#operation_get_a_list_of_countries).

ccExpiry.description: The user's credit card expiry date. It is in MM/YY format.

ccCVV.description: The card verification value. This is normally a three-digit number on the back of the user's credit card.

get.summary: Calculate total values of items in cart
get.description: Given a list of items and a user's country and payment method, this will calculate what the total charged to the user will be.

parameters.name: cart
parameters.description:
The cart parameter should contain a comma separated list of cart items, of which the parameters themselves are separated by slashes. There should always be three parameters.

A cart item looks like this: `39/1/30`

* The first parameter is the ID of the product
* The second parameter is the quantity required (if it's a subscription product, then this is the number of licences required).
* If it's a subscription, then this is the subscription ID of the product. If it is not a subscription, this value should be 0.

parameters.name: coupon
parameters.description: If the user has a discount code, this will be it.

parameters.name: country
parameters.description: This is the user's country ID and it is used to calculate whether tax should be applied to the order or not. A list of country IDs can be pulled down at [/site/countries](#operation_get_a_list_of_countries).

parameters.name: method
parameters.description:
The payment method selected.

| ID | Method |
| ----- | ----- |
| 1 | Credit card |
| 2 | Bank transfer |
| 3 | Cheque |

post.description: If you need an idea of the kind of results that will be returned when building an Alert, that can be done here.

get.summary: List Alerts for an account

freq.description:
The frequency that Alerts will be emailed to the user. The possible values are:

| Value | Type | Notes |
| ----- | ----- | ----- |
| 0 | Never | Never send an email. Useful if the customer is only using the RSS feeds or app. |
| 1 | Live | Send Alerts emails immediately for each article published. Unless the user has very specific filters set, this will result in a deluge of email. |
| 2 | Hourly | Send Alerts hourly, on the hour. |
| 3 | Daily | Send Alerts daily, at the time specified in the sendat parameter. |
| 4 | Weekly | Send Alerts weekly, usually at midnight UTC on a Monday morning. |
| 5 | Monthly | Send Alerts monthly. |

sendat.description: If an Alert is being sent daily, this is the time of day that it will be sent (based on UTC a timezone).

alerts.description: An array of Alerts, sorted by the user's preferences.

uid.description: The newly created Alert's unique identifier (for RSS feeds).

put.description: This will batch update/replace a user's alerts. The order of the array sent to the server will dictate the sort order of the user's Alerts. If an Alert is not sent to the server, it will be deleted.

alerts.description: The user's new Alerts, ordered. If this key is not sent, no Alerts will be changed.

freq.description: If you want to change Alert frequency settings, send this key.

The sending frequency of the user's Alerts.

| Value | Type | Notes |
| ----- | ----- | ----- |
| 0 | Never | Never send an email. Useful if the customer is only using the RSS feeds or app. |
| 1 | Live | Send Alerts emails immediately for each article published. Unless the user has very specific filters set, this will result in a deluge of email. |
| 2 | Hourly | Send Alerts hourly, on the hour. |
| 3 | Daily | Send Alerts daily, at the time specified in the sendat parameter. |
| 4 | Weekly | Send Alerts weekly, usually at midnight UTC on a Monday morning. |
| 5 | Monthly | Send Alerts monthly. |

sendat.description: The time to send Alerts if the frequency is set to daily. UTC timezone.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The user's ID.

get.summary: List articles for an Alert
get.description: This will return a list of articles that match the specified alert, in reverse-chronological order.

parameters.name: num
parameters.description: Maximum number of results to return.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: Zero-based result page index.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description: Don't show alerts newer than this time.

parameters.name: nolimit
parameters.description: By default, searches are restricted to stories from within the past 3 months, in order to keep response times fast. If you want to go back further, send this parameter.

put.description: This changes the search parameters of an Alert.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The user's account ID.

parameters.name: alertid
parameters.description: The user's Alert ID.

get.summary: Get a list of articles
get.description: Returns an array of articles in reverse-chronological order.

parameters.name: num
parameters.description: Maximum number of articles to return.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: Zero-based article page index.

parameters.name: categories
parameters.description:
A comma-separated list of category IDs to filter by.

This will do an intersect merge on the tags that feature within the categories, meaning that only tags included in all the categories listed will be used for filtering.

**IMPORTANT**: If a categories parameter is included, any alert parameter will be ignored.

parameters.name: alert
parameters.description: Either an Alert ID or unique idenfitier for an Alert to filter the results by.

parameters.name: profileid
parameters.description:
If you want to filter results by profile, then this will be the profile ID that you want to filter by.

Both profile ID and profile type are required for profile filtering.

parameters.name: profiletype
parameters.description:
If you want to filter results by profile, then this will be the profile type that you want to filter by.

Both profile ID and profile type are required for profile filtering.

parameters.name: linked
parameters.description: If this is set, then the content returned will be automatically linked to CAPA profiles on relevant keywords.

parameters.name: types
parameters.description:
Comma-separated list of news type IDs to return. This will override anything sent in the "type" parameter.

| ID | Type | Description |
| ----- | ----- | ----- |
| 1 | Analysis | Analysis articles. |
| 2 | Press Releases | CAPA press releases. |
| 3 | Direct News Sources | Other company press releases. |
| 4 | Share Market Performance | Legacy/unused. |
| 5 | Blog | Legacy/unused. |
| 6 | Updates | CAPA updates. Somehow different to CAPA press releases. |
| 7 | Financials | Legacy/unused. |
| 8 | Traffic | Legacy/unused.
| 9 | Airline Leader | Articles from Airline Leader. |

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of news to return. This is just an easier way of specifying news types than using the "types" parameter.

schema.description: Note that if a premium article has been requested and an authorization header has either not been sent or the user does not have membership or other access to the article, then the "article" key will not be included in the output.

get.summary: Get an article

errors.description: If the user hasn't got authorization to download the full version of a premium article, an error key will be returned along with the main data.

enum: This is a premium article that requires CAPA Membership to view.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Article ID.

get.summary: Generate a PDF of an article

200.description: The binary data for a PDF containing the article will be returned

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Article ID.

get.summary: Download an article attachment

200.description: A successful request will result in a binary stream of the file's contents being sent to the user.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Article ID.

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: Attached file to download.

get.summary: Get a list of news briefs
get.description: Returns an array of news briefs in reverse-chronological order.

parameters.name: num
parameters.description: Maximum number of results to return.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: Zero-based page index number.

parameters.name: categories
parameters.description:
A comma-separated list of category IDs to filter by.

This will do an intersect merge on the tags that feature within the categories, meaning that only tags included in all the categories listed will be used for filtering.

**IMPORTANT**: If a categories parameter is included, any alert parameter will be ignored.

parameters.name: alert
parameters.description: Either an Alert ID or unique idenfitier for an Alert to filter the results by.

parameters.name: profileid
parameters.description:
If you want to filter results by profile, then this will be the profile ID that you want to filter by.

Both profile ID and profile type are required for profile filtering.

parameters.name: profiletype
parameters.description:
If you want to filter results by profile, then this will be the profile type that you want to filter by.

Both profile ID and profile type are required for profile filtering.

parameters.name: linked
parameters.description: If this is set, then the content returned will be automatically linked to CAPA profiles on relevant keywords.

get.summary: Get a news brief

parameters.name: linked
parameters.description: If this flag is set, then the news brief content will be automatically linked to CAPA profiles on relevant keywords.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: News brief ID.

get.summary: List available videos

parameters.name: num
parameters.description: Maximum number of results to return.

The shorturl string.

Given a URL of `https://centreforaviation.com/data/profiles/airlines/qantas-airways-qf`, the shorturl component would be `qantas-airways-qf`.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description:
The type string.

Given a URL of `https://centreforaviation.com/data/profiles/airlines/qantas-airways-qf`, the type would be `airlines`.

get.summary: Get basic info for a profile
get.description:
This returns basic profile details - a short description, IATA/ICAO codes, location, etc. There are a few fields common to all profiles, however the resulting object will vary greatly depending on the profile type.

**IMPORTANT**: Profile IDs do not change - they will remain the same throughout their lifetime. The exception is in the rare event of a merge, when duplicate profiles are combined together. This is an administrative thing unrelated to airline mergers and does not happen often.

iata.description:
Profile IATA code.

Applies to:
* airlines
* airports

icao.description:
Profile ICAO code.

Applies to:
* airlines
* airports

duplicate.description:
Whether or not the profile's IATA code is a controlled duplicate.

Applies to:
* airlines

efrom.description:
Date that the company was effective ("active") from. A company that is currently active will have an efrom date of null or the date it started operating. If the date is in the future, it means the company has not started operating yet.

Applies to:
* airlines

eto.description:
Similar to efrom, this is the date that the company ceased operations. If it is null, it is assumed the company is active. If it is a date in the past, this is the date it ceased operating. If it is a future date, this is the date it will cease operating.

Applies to:
* airlines

current.description:
An easier way to tell if an airline is active or not - if it's true then it's an active airline.

Applies to:
* airlines

bizmodel.description:
Business model of the profile.

Applies to:
* airlines

category.description: News/analysis should match articles within this category.

stockid.description: The ID number of the stock ticker.

address.description:
The address of the profile. Typically a company's headquarters.

Applies to:
* airlines
* airports

hub.description:
If this is an airline profile, its main hub details are here.

Applies to:
* airlines

bio.description: A short HTML description of the profile.

currency.description: If the profile reports financials, the currency it reports in.

financial_year_end.description:
The month number that the profile's financial year ends in.

**IMPORTANT**: Note that this does not guarantee that financial data is available for the profile.

traffic_year_end.description:
The month number that the profile's traffic reporting year ends in.

**IMPORTANT**: Note that this does not guarantee that traffic data is available for the profile.

startup.description:
Whether or not CAPA classifies this profile as a startup.

Applies to:
* airlines

startupdate.description:
If this is a startup profile, this is the date that CAPA expects the airline to start operations. Note that this is a string and not a date field as the contents will vary depending on how accurate we can get.

Applies to:
* airlines

failedstartup.description:
True if this profile is classified as a failed startup.

Applies to:
* airlines

country.description: If the profile has a country associated with it, this is the country details.

schengen.description: True if this country is part of the Schengen Agreement.

region.description:
Region info for the profile.

Applies to:
* airlines
* airports

carriesfreight.description:
On airline profiles, this will be true if the airline carries freight.

Applies to:
* airlines

group.description:
If the airline is part of an airline group, here is the group details.

Applies to:
* airlines

majority.description: True if the airline group is a majority owner of this profile.

financial_year_end.description: Month number that the airline group's financial year ends.

traffic_year_end.description: Month number that the airline group's traffic year ends.

currency.description: Currency that the airline's financials are in.

joined.description: Year that the airline joined this alliance.

ownership.description:
String describing the profile's ownership status.

Applies to:
* airlines

status.description:
String describing the airline's status.

Applies to:
* airlines

domestic.description: True if this airline has a domestic network.

international.description: True if this airline has an international network.

image.description: Profile image (will most likely be a logo or a flag). [More information on resizing images](#text_resizing_images). Note that the image URL will always end with a question mark followed by a number - this is so cached old images are not served up by accident.

tags.description: Tags that news/analysis in the profile should match. Note that these are merged with any tags found in the `category` key.

trafficsource.description:
String describing where the traffic reports for this profile are sourced from.

Applies to:
* airports

others.description: Array of other airports located in the same city.

disabled.description:
True if this profile is disabled.

Applies to:
* airports

classification.description:
Denotes whether an airport is primary or secondary. If omitted it means no classification has been made.

Applies to:
* airports

code.description:
Country or region code.

Applies to:
* countries
* regions
* metaregions

latitude.description:
Latitude of where this profile is located.

Applies to:
* airports
* countries
* regions

longitude.description:
Longitude of where this profile is located.

Applies to:
* airports
* countries
* regions

fullname.description: If this key exists, it is the unabbreviated name of the profile. For example, the `name` key for the ACI profile is **ACI**, but the `fullname` key is **Airports Council International (ACI World)**.

subsidiaries.description:
An array containing details of the group's subsidiaries.

Applies to:
* airline groups

majority.description: True if the group has a majority ownership of this airline.

founded.description:
Year the alliance was founded.

Applies to:
* alliances

airports.description:
Airports the investor has an interest in.

Applies to:
* investors

investment.description:
Amount of investment (USD) going into the airport.

Applies to:
* new airports

throughput.description:
Expected PAX throughput. If this array has two entries, the first one is the initial throughput, and the last one is the expected throughput once completed. If there's only one item in the array then it's the throughput once completed.

Applies to:
* new airports

facilitysize.description:
Facility size.

Applies to:
* new airports

cargovolume.description:
Expected cargo volume at the airport.

Applies to:
* new airports

terminal.description:
Terminal details.

Applies to:
* new airports

width.description:
Width (metres) of the terminal.

Zero if unknown.

length.description:
Length (metres) of the terminal.

Zero if unknown.

area.description:
Area (square metres) of the terminal.

Zero if unknown.

completion.description:
Date the airport is expected to be built by.

Applies to:
* new airports

atcos.description:
Number of Air Transport Control Officers.

Applies to
* air traffic management

employees.description:
Number of employees.

Applies to
* air traffic management

accs.description:
Number of Area Control Centres. Zero if unknown.

Applies to
* air traffic management

towers.description:
Number of air traffic control towers.

Applies to
* air traffic management

members.description:
A comma-separated list of members.

Applies to:
* government bodies

parent.description: If this array exists, it contains a list of profiles that are considered "parents" of this profile.

financial_year_end.description: Month the parent profile's financial year ends.

groundhandlers.description:
Array of ground/cargo handlers at the airport.

Applies to:

* airports

fuelsuppliers.description:
List of fuel suppliers at the airport.

Applies to:

* airports

supplies.description:
List of airports that the supplier/MRO has bases at.

List of airports that the supplier supplies fuel to.

get.summary: Get a list of schedules for an airline/airport
get.description:
Look up schedules for airlines/airports. Schedules are provided by OAG and are subject to separate licensing agreements. Contact CAPA for more information.

At this point in time, schedules can be searched 2 weeks in the past up to 26 weeks in the future - accuracy lessens the further into the future you go. Beyond 23 weeks things get murky.

parameters.name: dep
parameters.description: Filter results for a given departure airport ID. Only applies to airline schedules.

parameters.name: arr
parameters.description: Filter results for a given arrival airport ID. Only applies to airline schedules.

parameters.name: airline
parameters.description: Filter results by airline ID. Only applies to airport schedules.

parameters.name: airport
parameters.description: Filter results so schedules either depart or arrive from this airport ID. Only applies to airport schedules.

parameters.name: week
parameters.description: ISO8601 string of the week to look up schedules for. The date sent needs to be a Monday. This will override the `from` and `to` parameters.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description: ISO8601 string of the date to look up schedules from.

parameters.name: to
parameters.description: ISO8601 string of the date to look up schedules to.

parameters.name: ftype
parameters.description: Flight type.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: Zero-based page number of results to return.

parameters.name: num
parameters.description: Number of results to return per page. If this is not sent, all results are returned (can be huge).

parameters.name: sort
parameters.description:
Schedules sorting. Can be one of the following values:

* **arriving** - arriving airport name
* **dftime** - descending flight time
* **aftime** - ascending flight time
* **atime** - ascending arrival time
* **dtime** - ascending departure time

parameters.name: stype
parameters.description: Service type.

parameters.name: atype
parameters.description: Aircraft ID to filter schedules by. These are different IDs to what are in the CAPA Fleet Database. Use IDs returned from ---

parameters.name: peak
parameters.description:
Filter by peak/offpeak schedules. Possible values:

* **peak** - schedules departing in peak tiimes
* **nonpeak** - schedules departing in offpeak times
* **arrpeak** - schedules arriving in peak times
* **arrnonpeak** - schedules arriving in offpeak times

If filtering by peak/offpeak, you need to send values through that define when peak/offpeak *is* - see below.

parameters.name: mfrom
parameters.description: The hour that morning peak starts.

parameters.name: mto
parameters.description: The hour that morning peak ends. Note that whatever value is given, 59 minutes past the hour is treated as the "end." So if you give a value of 8, then 8:59 is treated as the time that peak hour ends.

parameters.name: afrom
parameters.description: The hour that afternoon peak starts.

parameters.name: ato
parameters.description: The hour that afternoon peak ends. Note that whatever value is given, 59 minutes past the hour is treated as the "end." So if you give a value of 18, then 18:59 is treated as the time that peak hour ends.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: Profile type ID.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Profile ID.

get.summary: Get myairlease data about the aircraft
get.description: [myairlease](http://www.myairlease.com/) is a third-party website that tracks aircraft that are available for leasing. If an aircraft in the CAPA Fleet Database has a myairlease record associated with it, then data will be returned for this call.

data.description: myairlease data.

hours.description:
Reported hours that this aircraft has flown (this data is from myairlease, *not* the CAPA Fleet Database).

Zero if unknown/not supplied.

cycles.description:
Reported cycles that this aircraft has flown (this data is from myairlease, *not* the CAPA Fleet Database).

Zero if unknown/not supplied.

olas.description:
String listing the types of leasing available. Lease types are separated by a slash.

Types:
* **OL**: operating lease
* **A**: ACMI
* **S**: sale

year.description: Year the aircraft was listed.

ad.description:
Date the aircraft is available from.

If this key does not exist, then it is assumed that the aircraft is immediately available.

month.description: Month the aircraft is available from.

year.description: Year the aircraft is available from.

seats.description:
Listed seat configuration. Note this is data from myairlease and *not* the CAPA Fleet Database.

If this key does not exist, then seating configuration information was not provided.

lessor.description: This is the company managing the lease/sale.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Aircraft ID.

data.description: An array of valuation data. Each entry corresponds to what the aircraft was worth at the time of valuation. So an entry for November 2014 would be what ICF considered that aircraft to be worth back then.

year.description: Year of valuation.

months.description: Array of months with valuation data.

lr.description:
Monthly lease rate.

Values listed are in multiples of 1 million.

br.description:
Base rate.

Values listed are in multiples of 1 million.

mr.description:
Market rate.

Values listed are in multiples of 1 million.

parameters.description:
T100 field ID.

# **Load factors** #
Getting load factor data has a bit of a quirk to it. If you wish to retrieve load factors, `field` should be set to the values that have a `loadfactor: true` key returned from a call to list fields, separated by a pipe.

So if you do a call to /fields and it returns a list of fields, and two of those fields have `loadfactor: true` (let's say they have an ID of 4 and 5), then if you were to use `5|4` as the field ID, it would return load factor values. Alternatively you could pull down the PAX and seats fields separately and do the load factor calculation yourself.

An array of news types to include in results.

News types are:

| ID | Type | Description |
| ----- | ----- | ----- |
| 0 | News | News briefs. |
| 1 | Analysis | Analysis articles. |
| 2 | Press Releases | CAPA press releases. |
| 3 | Direct News Sources | Other company press releases. |
| 4 | Share Market Performance | Legacy/unused. |
| 5 | Blog | Legacy/unused. |
| 6 | Updates | CAPA updates. Somehow different to CAPA press releases. |
| 7 | Financials | Legacy/unused. |
| 8 | Traffic | Legacy/unused.
| 9 | Airline Leader | Articles from Airline Leader. |

search.description: An array of condition groups to filter news by.

type.description: Whether to match all or any of the conditions included.

match.description:
Set to true if you want to include results that match everything, or false if you want to do a negative match.

Negative matches only work when there is more than one condition group. These are so you can go "match these tags but not those tags."

cats.description: An array of category IDs. A list of IDs can be found at [/site/categories](#operation_get_a_list_of_available_categories).

Alert.description: An Alert object is a description of the parameters and values that make up a single Alert. This will be used to match stories that will be returned to the user.

id.description: Issue ID (don't confuse with issue number).

issue.description: Issue number (don't confuse with issue ID).

title.description:
Issue title (usually blank).

Issue title (usually blank).

date.description: UNIX timestamp of the issue publication date.

shortname.description: Publication shortname - a short, unique lowercase abbreviation identifying the publication.

description.description: HTML description of the issue (usually blank).

password.description: File password. A long time ago we used to distribute issues as password-protected PDFs. This has not been done for many years now.

shortdesc.description: Short, one-sentence text description of the report.

description.description: Longer, multi-paragraph HTML description of the report.

currency.description: 3-letter code of the currency the report is in.

type.description:
The report type.

| ID | Type |
| ----- | ----- |
| 0 | A free report, available to all people with a CAPA Account. |
| 1 | A paid report that must be purchased separately. |

image.description:
The image URL for the report, if it is a paid report. Details on resizing images are [here](#text_resizing_images).

Free reports (type = 0) will not have an image URL. You can generate a thumbnail URL instead by using a URL of `https://images.cdn.centreforaviation.com/files/reports/{id}/{image}`

In this situation, {id} is the report ID and {image} is an image filename that is generated based upon the filename of the report, minus its extension and with a width parameter set. It is the same parameter format used for [resizing images](#text_resizing_images), however only the width parameter works. For example, if the report's filename is `Daily_News_3.pdf` then a valid image filename would be `Daily_News_3-400x.jpg` - this would give a 400 pixel wide thumbnail image of the first page of the report.

url.description: The URL of the report info page.

timestamp.description: A UNIX timestamp value of the last date the report file was modified. This will only appear for free reports, not paid ones.

info.description: A short, one-sentence text description of the event.

city.description: The city the event is being held in.

country.description: The country the event is being held in.

region.description: The metaregion the event is being held in.

date.description: The date of the event. Dates are in the timezone of the event's city.

start.description: The start date of the event, in ISO8601 format.

end.description: The end date of the event, in ISO8601 format.

certain.description: Whether or not the dates for this event are certain, or just placeholder dates.

tech.description: Whether this event has an IT-focused component or not.

finance.description: Whether this event has a finance focused component or not.

corporate.description: Whether this event has a corporate travel focused component or not.

airline.description: Whether this event has an airline focus or not.

airport.description: Whether this event has an airport focus or not.

australasia.description: True if this is a CAPA-ACTE event.

splash.description: The URL for an event splash image, if available. Info on [resizing images](#text_resizing_images).

description.description: A short description of the article, for use as a meta description tag.

abstract.description: The article abstract. This will be the first paragraph or two of an article.

article.description: The article content. Concatenate this with the article abstract to get the full article. This will only be returned on individual article requests.

ad.description: This will be true if ads should be displayed within the article.

keypoints.description: A plaintext list of key points for an article. Not really used anymore.

featured.description: Treat this article as a featured article.

image.description: Article image URL. See [resizing](#text_resizing_images) for info on getting the correct image size.

premium.description: Whether or not this is a premium article. If it is and the user has no access to the article, then the "article" key will be omitted from the result.

price.description: The price of a premium article. Left over from when we used to sell access to individual articles, and is unused now.

tags.description: An array of tags for the article.

timestamp.description: UNIX timestamp of the article date.

type.description: The news type of the article.

files.description:
If the article has files attached to it for download, then they will be listed here. This key will only be included on individual article requests.

[Documentation on downloading attachments](#operation_download_an_article_attachment).

mro.description: A list of MRO Matrix record IDs associated with the article.

message.description: A short description of what the error was.

status.description: The closest equivalent HTTP status code. This will usually match the HTTP status code that has been sent from the response.

Error.description:
This is an error response. It will be returned if there's any problems with the request. Note that is possible to have both data and errors returned in the one response, although it doesn't happen often.

The errors array will always have at least one element. The errors are in the array in an unspecified order - none is seen as more severe than the other.

url.description: Video URL on the CAPA site.

date.description: UNIX timestamp of when the video was published.

event.description: Event the video was filmed at

id.description: Event ID if it was a CAPA event.

start.description: ISO8601 date that the event started.

end.description: ISO8601 date that the event ended.

certain.description: True if we are certain about these dates (will virtually always be true, as if a video is associated with an event it means the event has already happened).

url.description: If the event has a historical post-event info page, this will be the URL of it.

vimeoid.description: Vimeo ID number of the video. Zero if not a Vimeo video.

embed.description: URL of the video if it is not hosted on Vimeo. Blank if it is.

transcript.description: A transcript of the video, if available.

airline.description: Details of the airline operating the flight.

alliance.description: If the airline is in an alliance, details will be here.

wetlease.description: If the airline is operating the flight as part of a wetlease, this is the wetlease details.

id.description: Aircraft ID. Does not match CAPA Fleet Database.

from.description: This schedule is active from this date.

to.description: This schedule expires on this date.

days.description:
Bitwise mask of the days of the week that this schedule operates on. The position of each bit tells the day of the week it operates.

So 1 bitshifted 0 times gives a decimal value of 1, which means the schedule operated on Sunday only (this assumes Sunday = 0).

A decimal value of 3 would translate to 11 in binary, mean Sunday and Monday. Decimal 2 in binary would be 10, which would mean Monday only (because Monday is the 1st day of the week if we're counting from zero (Sunday being the 0th day of the week), and the binary 10 means a bit is set for the 1st position).

day.description: If a schedule departs and arrives on the same day, this is `0`. If it arrives the next day, it's `1`. If it arrives 2 days later, it's `2`. In rare cases where the schedule arrives before it departs (due to flying against a timezone), this will be `-1`.

type.description: Schedule type. See [schedule types](#text_schedule_types) for the full list.

restrictions.description: Any traffic restriction codes. See [traffic restriction codes](#text_traffic_restriction_codes) for the full list.

seats.description: Seat details. Note that these are estimated based on values from the CAPA Fleet Database.

peclass.description: Number of premium economy class seats.

air.description: Number of minutes spent in the air. Currently this is the entire length of the flight.

ground.description: Number of minutes spent on the ground. Currently this will always be `0`.

flight.description: Length of the flight (in kilometres). Currently this is always identical to the length of the route.

payload.description: Cargo payload (kg). This is estimated based on numbers from the CAPA Fleet Database.

codeshares.description: If any airlines operate this flight via codeshare, their details are here.

stops.description: If the flight has any stopovers, the flights that make up this entire schedule will be listed here in order.

types.description: An array of service types. See the full list [here](#text_schedule_types).

shortdesc.description: A short, one sentence text description of the shop item.

description.description: A longer, more in-depth HTML description of the shop item.

price.description: The price (or setup fee) of the shop item. For single-purchase items like reports or event passes, this will be the price of the item. For subscriptions, this will be treated as a one-off setup fee for the subscription and added to the subscription pricing.

currency.description: The currency of the product. This will almost always be USD.

mailout.description: Boolean indicating whether or not this product contains a mailing list component.

type.description:
Product type. This is currently used for a simple differentiation between reports and all other types of product.

* 0 will indicate that the product is not a report.
* 1 indicates the product is a report.

There is the potential for other values to be added in the future, if more complex shop product types are introduced.

filename.description: This is a legacy field indicating the filename for a product if it is downloadable. This will be blank and you should rely on the `files` array instead.

period.description: The length of time (in months) that the subscription is valid for.

price.description: The price for the subscription period.

files.description: An array of files that are provided by the product.

image.description:
If an image for this product is available, then this is its URL. Check [here](#text_resizing_images) for info on resizing images.

If there is no image available, this will be a null value.

url.description: The URL for the information/purchase page for this product.

years.description:
An array of years that the financial field has data for. Note that only full years are returned here, not split years. `2016` might mean `2016` or it could mean `2016/17` depending on the company's profile. To find out what month a company's financial year ends in, check the basic profile info result.

Note that the years returned may be out of order and may have holes (although it's unlikely).

children.description: If there's any child fields of this field, they will be listed here.

isPercent.description: If the values for this field should be treated as a percentage, this will be `true`.

showGrowth.description: If `true`, then graphs on the CAPA site should display growth year-on-year for this value.

values.description: An array of values for this field.

year.description: The year this applies to. Note that this is the **financial year**, so it depends on the company's locale as to if it's a normal whole year, or if it's a split year, like `2016/17`.

period.description: Period number .This will always be a zero if we're looking at annual figures, otherwise it's a 1-based index.

note.description: If there's any notes about this value, they'll be here.

grouping.description: If there's another grouping for this value, it will be here.

local.description: The value, as expressed in the company's local currency.

usd.description: The value, converted to USD (average USD conversion rate for the period that the value applied to is used). If we have no conversion rate, or the value is already USD then this won't be included.

children.description: If this field has child fields, then they'll be listed here.

years.description: An array of years that the tourism field has data for.

children.description: If there's any child fields of this field, they will be listed here.

isPercent.description: If the values for this field should be treated as a percentage, this will be `true`.

showGrowth.description: If `true`, then graphs on the CAPA site should display growth year-on-year for this value.

values.description: An array of values for this field.

year.description: The year this applies to.

period.description: Period number. This will always be a zero if we're looking at annual figures, otherwise it's a 1-based index.

note.description: If there's any notes about this value, they'll be here.

grouping.description: If there's another grouping for this value, it will be here.

children.description: If this field has child fields, then they'll be listed here.

year.description: The year that the values apply to.

total.description: Total number of domestic seats (including LCC) flown.

lcc.description: Total number of LCC domestic seats flown.

total.description: Total number of international seats (including LCC) flown.

lcc.description: Total number of international LCC seats flown.

incomplete.description: This will exist and be `true` if the data for this year is incomplete.

id.description: Airline ID. Will be `null` if there's no match between our profile database and OAG's.

type.description: Airline type ID. Will always be 1.

url.description: Airline profile URL. Null if we don't have one.

from.description: Month number (1 = January) that this airline was counted as an LCC from.

to.description: Month number (1 = January) that this airline counts as an LCC to.

startup.description: True if this airline is a startup.

failedstartup.description: True if this airline is a failed startup.

hidden.description: True if this profile should be hidden.

total.description: The total USD value of the investment.

estimated.description: True if the total is a number estimated by CAPA.

total.description: Total current PAX traffic.

estimated.description: True if this value is estimated by CAPA.

total.description: Total future PAX traffic.

estimated.description: True if this value is estimated by CAPA, false if it is estimated by the airport.

year.description: Anticipated year that these passenger numbers will be reached. Zero if not specified.

total.description: Total current annual freight (tonnes).

estimated.description: True if this value is estimated by CAPA.

total.description: Total future annual freight (tonnes).

estimated.description: True if this value is estimated by CAPA, false if it is estimated by the airport.

year.description: Anticipated year that this total will be reached. Zero if not specified.

airport.description: If this optional key exists, it details the airport that this construction project applies to. If not, it is because the project is assigned to a country.

type.description: Airport profile type. Note that an airport could be classified as either an "airport" or a "new airport" so there's two possible types here. See [Profile Types](#text_profile_types) for more information.

iata.description: Airport IATA code. Null if unavailable.

icao.description: Airport ICAO code. Null if unavailable.

type.description: Investor profile type. An investor may be an "investor," but it's also possible for it to be an airline or another airport, so don't assume that this will always be a profile type of "investor." More info on [profile types](#text_profile_types).

major.description: True if the investor is classified as a "major" investor. Not a major investor in the airport, but as a major investor worldwide.

year.description: Year the airline joined the alliance.

article.description: HTML content of the article itself.

image.description: Article image URL. [More info on resizing](#text_resizing_images).

Alert Result.description: A single Alert result will contain an article and all the content for it.

peclass.description: Number of premium economy class seats.

total.description: Total number of seats. Note that this value may not always be equal to fclass + bclass + peclass + eclass on older records, as we originally did not count seats by class, only their totals.

freight.description: Freight values. On older records these may be empty.

belly.description: Kilograms carried in the bellyhold of a passenger jet.

total.description: Total freight carried.

arrfreq.description:
Number of arriving frequencies.

**IMPORTANT**: This key is not included when pulling down values for regions.

article.description: HTML content of news brief. This will not be returned if the articles is not a headline and the user is not logged in with membership access.

date.description: UNIX timestamp of the news brief's date.

tags.description: An array of tags that the news brief has been tagged with.

mro.description: A list of MRO Matrix record IDs associated with the article.

premium.description: True if this article is not available for free.

isPercent.description: True if the data returned is a percentage instead of a normal number.

showGrowth.description: Whether or not to show the growth values in resulting charts based on this data.

year.description: Traffic data year.

period.description: Period number. If this is a monthly field, this will be the month of the year. If it is quarterly, it will be the year quarter.

note.description: If there's any notes attached to this record, they'll be here in plaintext.

grouping.description: If there's an extra string grouping on this field, it will be here.

children.description: If there are child fields with data, they will be contained here.

years.description: An array of years that have data for this traffic field.

children.description: If there are any child fields, they will be listed here.

country.description: If the profile has a country linked to it, country details are here.

stockid.description: This value will appear if doing a share price search.

search.description: This will be an object of fleet search parameters.

columns.description: An array of columns to display for the search. This is currently unused and subject to change.

myairlease.description: True if this record has myairlease data available.

winglets.description: True if this aircraft has aftermarket winglets fitted.
True if this aircraft variant comes with stock winglets.

mtow.description: Generic maximum takeoff weight for this aircraft variant (kg).

engines.description: Number of engines this variant has.

myairlease.description: The myairlease name for this aircraft model.

peclass.description: Number of premium economy class seats.

line.description: Aircraft line number (if available). This is for Boeing aircraft.

block.description: Aircraft variable block identifier. This is for Boeing aircraft.

mro.description:
Hours and cycles information (if available).

This key will exist if the aircraft has hours/cycles information and the user has access to it.

year.description: Year the hours/cycles applies to.

month.description: Month the hours/cycles applies to (1 = January).

total.description: Total hours registered for the aircraft up until the given month.

month.description: Number of hours flown for the aircraft for the given month.

total.description: Total cycles registered for the aircraft up until the given month.

month.description: Number of cycles flown for the aircraft for the given month.

valuation.description: ICF aircraft valuation information if it exists and the user has access to them. Note that valuations are generic to the variant.

year.description: Valuation year.

manufactured.description: If date of manufacture information is available, it is here.

year.description: Year of manufacture.

delivered.description: If delivery information is available, it is here.

year.description: Year of aircraft delivery.

month.description:
Month of aircraft delivery.

If the delivery date is greater than 2 years in the future, this value will not exist.

day.description:
Day of aircraft delivery.

If the delivery date is greater than  6 months in the future, this value will not exist.

generic.description: True if this APU is generic to the variant, false if it is aftermarket.

from.description: Date that the record was effective from.

to.description: Date that the record is effective to. Will be null if the record is considered to be currently effective.

multiple.description:
If a date range has been used as a query parameter and there are multiple records for a single aircraft returned for that date range, then they will contain a `multiple` key.

The key can have three possible values - `first`, `multiple` and `final`.

* **first** is the first (oldest) record for that range.
* **multiple** will be applied to any records between `first` and `final`
* **final** is the last (newest) record for that range.

operator.description: If the aircraft has an operator assigned to it, the details of it will here here.

country.description: If country data exists for the operator, it's here.

owner.description: If owner information is available, it is here.

type.description: Owner type ID. This will be 1 for airlines and 3 for lessors.

substantative.description:
Substantative owner information, if available.

Due to tax laws etc, it's common for aircraft to be owned by shell corporations, which will be the values you see in the `owner` key. The substantative owner is who we believe to be the "real" owner of the aircraft.

type.description: Substantative owner type ID. This will be 1 for airlines or 3 for lessors.

sublessor.description: If sublessor information is available, it is here.

type.description: Sublessor type ID. This will be 1 for airlines and 3 for lessors.

to.description: Date the lease ended. Null if ongoing.

certain.description: True if this lease information has been confirmed.

storage.description: If the aircraft is currently in storage, this is the details of the airport it is stored at.

url.description: Airport profile URL. Will be null if there is no active profile.

announced.description: Date the MRO contract was announced.

date.description: This will be an ISO8601 date if the date the contract was announced is known, otherwise it will be null.

exact.description: Whether or not to treat the date as "exact" in the case of [special dates](#text_special_dates).

date.description: This will be an ISO8601 date if the date the contract began is known, otherwise it will be null.

exact.description: Whether or not to treat the date as "exact" in the case of [special dates](#text_special_dates).

complete.description: Date that the contract was completed.

date.description: This will be an ISO8601 date if the date the contract was completed is known, otherwise it will be null.

exact.description: Whether or not to treat the date as "exact" in the case of [special dates](#text_special_dates).

completed.description: If the contract was completed, this will be true. It is possible for both the date to be null and this value to be true - this indicates that we know the contract was completed, but we don't know when.

term.description: Number of months the contract runs for.

units.description: Number of aircraft/engines/etc that the contract covers.

fixed.description: Fixed number of aircraft/engines/etc that the contract covers. Zero if unknown.

option.description: Number of aircraft/engines/etc that are on option for contract coverage. Zero if unknown.

inhouse.description: True if this is a contract that is being handled in-house by the contractor.

ondelivery.description: True if this contract commences when the first aircraft/engine is delivered.

exclusive.description: True if this contract is exclusive.

value.description: Value of the contract in USD. Zero if unknown.

notes.description: Any notes added about the contract by CAPA.

updated.description: UNIX timestamp of when this record was last updated.

contractors.description: List of contractors for this contract.

tender.description: If this contract is out for tender, this is the due date for it (ISO8601).

authorities.description: List of authorities for this contract.

interest.description: Area of interest covered by the authority.

brokers.description: A list of brokers/financiers for this contact.

children.description: A list of children/joint ventures that apply to the contract.

designers.description: A list of designers/developers associated with the contract.

contracts.description: A list of contract types the contract covers.

subsystems.description: List of subsystems this contract covers.

child.description: If this record specifically references a subsystem that is a child of a major subsystem category, it will be in here.

aircraft.description: This object contains details of the aircraft covered by the contract.
This is an array of aircraft objects that can be directly mapped against the CAPA Fleet database. This will be populated when we know the exact models/variants that this contract covers.

models.description: If we know the exact models that this contract covers, this data will be populated as well.

series.description: If we know the aircraft variant series this contract covers, it will be in this array.

variants.description: This is an array of aircraft variants (if known).

groups.description: This is an array that contains aircraft groups. These don't directly map to the CAPA Fleet database. This is used when the existing "aircraft" values are not suitable for describing what the contract covers.

roles.description: This array describes aircraft that are not in the above two categories by role. So this might contain values like "military" etc. These do not directly map to the CAPA Fleet Database.

engines.description: This object contains engines that this contract applies to.
This will contain an array of engine manufacturers, then within that it will break down to models and engines if they are known.

id.description: Engine manufacturer ID. This will map to the CAPA Fleet Database.

models.description: If known, engine models are listed here.

id.description: Engine model ID. This maps to the CAPA Fleet Database.

engines.description: Engines. This will map to the CAPA Fleet Database.

groups.description: This will list engine groups - these are types of engines that don't really fit into the above engines list.

id.description: Engine group ID. This does not match anything in the CAPA Fleet Database.

roles.description: Engine roles. Like aircraft roles, this is used when we can't really fit the description in anywhere else.

apus.description: Like engines and aircraft, this object contains APU details in the same sort of format.
Array of APU manufacturers. This maps to the CAPA Fleet Database.

models.description: APU models. This will map to the CAPA Fleet Database.

apus.description: APUs. This maps to the CAPA Fleet Database.

groups.description: Array of APU groups. This doesn't match anything in the CAPA Fleet Database.

sources.description: A list of news sources related to this contract.

MRO Result.description: An MRO result, as returned by the MRO Matrix.

id.description: News/analysis article ID. If this key does not exist, then the source is an external, non-CAPA URL.

news.description: True if this story is a news brief, false if it's a regular article. Use this to decide if you're pulling down the article from [/news](#operation_get_a_News%20Brief) or [/articles](#operation_get_an_article).

timestamp.description: UNIX timestamp of the data of the news source.

MRO Source.description: This is an MRO source object. The purpose of it is to list URLs for sources that the MRO contract was created from.

search.description: This will be an object of fleet search parameters.

columns.description: An array of columns to display for the search. This is currently unused and subject to change.

year.description: The year that this record refers to.

month.description: The month that this record refers to (1-indexed, so 1 = January).

value.description: The value of the field requested.

pax.description: If a load factor field has been requested, then the passenger count will be returned here.

seats.description: If a load factor field has been requested, then the seat count will be returned here.

percent.description: If this key exists and has a true value, then the number given in the value key should be treated as a percentage.

year.description: Year that the included values apply to.

values.description: A list of values. Note that this may not be in order.

seats.description: Seat rank number (ranked by number of available seats for the current week).

asks.description: ASKs rank number (ranked by number of ASKs for the current week).

freight.description: Freight rank number (ranked by cargo payload kg for the current week).

aftks.description: AFTKs rank number (ranked by AFTKs for the current week).

frequency.description: Frequency rank number (ranked by number of departing frequencies for the current week).

total.description: Total number of entities being ranked.

values.description: These are the values that make up the profile ranking.

seats.description: Number of seats for the current week.

asks.description: Number of ASKs for the current week.

freight.description: Amount of cargo (kg) for the current week.

aftks.description: Number of AFTKs for the current week.

frequency.description: Number of departing frequencies for the current week.
